all_paragraphs: This is the second article I am writing about Machine Learning in Riemannian Manifold. This time it is the extension of Principal Component Analysis(PCA) to Riemannian space. Readers are expected to have an understanding of PCA. To recall PCA once again, the following article can be helpful Understanding the Mathematics behind Principal Component Analysis. I also recommend readers to go through my previous article on Geodesic Regression where necessary concepts on Riemannian geometry are discussed.

PCA is a well-known technique for data analysis by representing the data in terms of its principal constituents. Two of the well-known applications of PCA are noise reduction and dimensionality reduction. Let’s review PCA with a simple example of noise reduction.
Real-world data are noisy. Noise can be introduced by the environment where we collect data or by the collection procedure itself. Let’s discuss the scenario in Figure 2.

The dotted data points on the left are the output from the source. As we can see the source can be perfectly modeled by line P1, meaning that the nature of output from the source is one-dimensional. P1 is the principal component in this case. On the right, we can see that when the source output is polluted with noise, there is not a perfect fit just with P1. The data points now tend to extend in the dimension perpendicular to the line. To get a perfect fit here, we need another principal component P2 perpendicular to P1. Now we can represent noisy data points as linear combinations of P1 and P2.

When we are to model a source by analyzing noisy data, we need to find a way to nullify the effect of noise for better modeling. PCA serves that purpose. When we project data into principal components, we can clearly visualize the significance of each component. Like in Figure 2, component P2 is less pronounced than P1 and we can infer that P2 has arisen due to noise and has to do little with the data source. In such a case, P2 can be discarded as noise and P1 can be used to model the source. The fact that noise components are less pronounced is because noise values carry less or no correlation to one another while the source output is highly correlated.

Likewise data like images, despite being represented in thousands of dimensions, contain most of the information only in their few principal components. Thus, when we subject such data for processing, insignificant components can be discarded keeping only a few significant ones thereby largely reducing dimensionality. This will make data processing efficient.

There are many ways to calculate PCA, the most effective one being the calculation of Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of the data matrix. Mathematically, major principal components are the ones that have the highest variances of the projection of data points onto them.

Just like in the previous article where we extended Linear Regression to data lying in the Riemannian space, we will now extend PCA to finding principal components for data lying in the same. This is called Principal Geodesic Analysis and we will find out the major geodesics that represent the given data.
We will make use of the mathematics we discussed in the previous article. So, if you haven’t already, I would once again recommend you to go through the article before moving forward.
Before going to PGA, let’s define the concept of mean in Riemannian space which we call Intrinsic Mean.
The mean of a set of data points is a point, the sum of the distance from all the data points to which is minimum.

In Euclidean space, this is easily computed by dividing the total vector sum of all data points by the number of data points. But, in general manifolds, the unique existence of mean cannot be guaranteed. However, if we have a well-localized data set, the mean exists and is unique. Now, we will generate synthetic data and carry out PGA on it. We will take data points lying on two geodesics with tangent vectors v1 and v2 centered at point p and add random noise to them to get our data points. Furthermore, there are 20 points along with the first and 10 points along the second geodesic. Finally, we will concatenate data points to create a data matrix y.
Now, calculating principal geodesics are fairly simple. We will just carry out 3 steps as described in the previous section.

We can see that the major two principal vectors we get (in the decreasing order of magnitudes) have a similar direction to the vectors v1 and v2 we used when generating data points and that the mean is also close to p. Please note that we need not compare magnitudes of v1 and v2 with obtained principal vectors because we are interested in finding out the principal geodesics and it is only the position and the direction of geodesic orientation that matters. Furthermore, a change in the magnitude of principal vectors will change the length of geodesics which is not so significant.
Finally, we can define geodesics by an Exponential map of mean and two major principal vectors obtained. Figure 4 closely depicts the scenario in the example:

The dotted points are synthesized data points along two geodesics and the two red curves are geodesics G1 and G2 fitted to the data points. The intersection of data points is the mean point. So, we can clearly observe that we have represented the data points by two principal geodesics.
